{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12291,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Opuntia ficus-indica, commonly known as the prickly pear cactus, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. Water the cactus deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season in spring and summer, water once every two to four weeks. In the fall and winter, reduce watering to once a month or less to avoid root rot. Always use well-draining soil and pots with drainage holes to prevent excess moisture from harming the plant. Overwatering is the most common mistake, so err on the side of underwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Opuntia ficus-indica thrives in full sun and requires plenty of direct sunlight to grow and produce vibrant pads. Ideally, the cactus should receive at least six to eight hours of sunlight each day. It can be grown outdoors in sunny, dry areas or indoors near a south-facing window where it can receive adequate light. If grown indoors, periodically rotate the plant to ensure even sun exposure on all sides. Insufficient sunlight may result in stunted growth and less vibrant coloration, so ensuring ample sun exposure is key to keeping the plant healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Opuntia ficus-indica is not always necessary, but it can help maintain the plant's size and shape, as well as remove any damaged or diseased pads. It is best to prune in the spring before new growth begins. Use a pair of sharp, clean pruning shears to cut away unwanted pads at the joints. Be sure to wear gloves to protect yourself from the cactus's spines. The removed pads can be replanted to propagate new cacti if desired. Regularly inspect the plant for any signs of rot or pest infestations and remove affected areas promptly."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Indian fig opuntia","description":"Opuntia ficus-indica is a species of cactus that has long been a domesticated crop plant important in agricultural economies throughout arid and semiarid parts of the world. It is thought probably to have originated in Mexico. Some of the common English names for the plant and its fruit are Indian fig opuntia, Barbary fig, cactus pear, spineless cactus, and prickly pear, although this last name has also been applied to other less common Opuntia species. In...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Indian fig opuntia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Opuntia ficus-indica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13091,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia terracina is a drought-tolerant plant, so it should be watered sparingly. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent overwatering, as waterlogged soil can lead to root rot. During the growing season, water the plant every 10-14 days, but reduce the frequency during the winter when the plant is dormant. It's essential to use well-draining soil to assist with proper drainage and avoid retaining excess moisture. Adjust watering frequency based on the climate conditions and the plant's environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia terracina thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers about 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily but can tolerate some light shade. If planted indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight. Ensure it doesn't experience intense afternoon sun that might scald it, especially in hotter climates. If growing outdoors, ensure it is in a location that receives sufficient morning sun while protecting it from the harshest midday rays. Adjust light conditions based on the plant's response to avoid issues with growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Euphorbia terracina involves removing dead, damaged, or diseased stems to promote healthy growth. Prune in the early spring before new growth begins, using clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts. If the plant becomes too large or leggy, it can be pruned back to maintain a desired shape and size. Wear gloves when pruning, as the milky sap can be irritating to the skin and eyes. Dispose of pruned material properly and clean tools after use to prevent sap residue."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"carnation spurge","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["carnation spurge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia terracina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, maintaining a humid environment is beneficial if attempting to grow it for study or ornamental purposes. It thrives in moist conditions, often found in damp, shaded forested areas. For best results, mimic these natural moisture conditions using a spray bottle to mist the area around the fungus lightly, rather than direct watering, to prevent the surrounding substrate from drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clavulina coralloides thrives in shaded environments typical of forest floors; hence, it prefers indirect, filtered sunlight. This will help preserve its moisture requirements and overall growth habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Clavulina coralloides as it is a fungus and not a plant, but if you are maintaining a culture for ornamental or scientific purposes, ensure that you manage any accompanying substrate carefully. Removing any decayed or dead organic matter around it can help in preventing unwanted microbial growth. Avoid physical disturbance of the fungal structure as it can damage the delicate mycelium unless it’s part of a deliberate cultivation or harvesting process."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"White Coral Fungus","description":"Clavulina cristata, commonly known as the white coral fungus or the crested coral fungus, is a white- or light-colored edible coral mushroom present in temperate areas of the Americas and Europe. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. If grown in pots, ensure the container has drainage holes to avoid standing water. During its dormant period in late fall to winter, reduce watering significantly, as the plant requires less moisture when not actively growing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oxalis violacea thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive about 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. However, it can tolerate light shade, especially in hotter climates, where protection from intense midday sun is beneficial to prevent leaf burn. If grown indoors, place the plant near a bright windowsill where it can receive adequate sunlight. Adjustments to sunlight exposure may be needed based on the plant’s response and overall climate conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oxalis violacea is minimal as the plant naturally maintains a compact form. However, during the growing season, you can remove spent flowers to encourage new blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. After the flowering period, cutting back any dead or yellowing foliage improves the plant’s overall aesthetics and health. Prune again if necessary in the fall as the plant enters dormancy to remove any remaining withered parts. Regular removal of dead or unhealthy leaves helps to prevent disease and pest issues."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"violet woodsorrel","description":"Oxalis violacea, the violet wood-sorrel, is a perennial plant and herb in the Oxalidaceae family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14077,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Scabiosa columbaria, commonly known as the small scabious, prefers well-drained soil and moderate watering. It is important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During the active growing season in spring and summer, water the plant once a week, adjusting frequency based on rainfall and drought conditions. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering to once every two to three weeks. Always check the soil moisture before watering by inserting your finger into the top inch of soil to ensure it isn't overly wet."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scabiosa columbaria thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. The plant requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal blooming. In extremely hot climates, a bit of afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching and prolong bloom time. Ensure that the planting location receives adequate sunlight during the morning and early afternoon. If the plant is growing in too much shade, it might become leggy and produce fewer blooms. Checking for suitable sunlight exposure during different seasons is crucial to ensure the plant blooms continuously and remains healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Scabiosa columbaria is important to encourage healthy growth and prolong blooming. Deadhead spent flowers regularly throughout the growing season to prevent seed formation and stimulate further blooming. In early spring, cut back any dead or damaged stems to about an inch above the base to tidy up the plant and encourage fresh new growth. Additionally, trimming back the foliage in late autumn after the foliage has died back can help maintain the plant’s shape and promote vigorous growth in the following year. Avoid cutting into the woody stems too harshly as it can damage the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Small Scabious","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","Africa"],"other_name":["Small Scabious"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Scabiosa columbaria"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13489,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pluchea sericea, also known as arrowweed, is quite drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering once established. In its native arid environments, it relies on infrequent rainfall and groundwater sources. In a garden setting, water deeply but infrequently. It is important to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the hotter summer months, slightly increase watering frequency, but still ensure that the soil drain well. Reduce watering in the cooler months when the plant’s growth naturally slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arrowweed thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally. It mimics its natural habitat by being planted in a location where it receives uninhibited exposure to sunlight, essential for both flowering and maintaining a compact growth habit. While it can tolerate some partial shade, prolonged periods without direct sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. In an indoor setting, place it near a south-facing window or in a similarly bright location to replicate its preferred conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pluchea sericea is not typically necessary, but can be performed to maintain a desired shape or to remove dead or unhealthy branches. If pruning for shape, do so in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to make precise cuts. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13294,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lycopodium clavatum, also known as Staghorn Clubmoss, prefers a moist environment similar to its native habitat, but it should not be waterlogged. Water the plant regularly, ensuring that the soil is consistently moist but not saturated. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. During the growing season, increase the frequency of watering, and reduce it during the plant’s dormant phase in the winter. Using distilled or rainwater is beneficial since clubmoss can be sensitive to chlorine and other chemicals in tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lycopodium clavatum prefers bright, indirect sunlight. It thrives under filtered light conditions, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. Direct sunlight may scorch its delicate leaves, so it is vital to protect the plant from harsh, direct sun exposure, especially during peak hours. If grown indoors, placing it near a north or east-facing window would be ideal. During the winter months, when daylight is reduced, you may need to supplement natural light with fluorescent grow lights to ensure the plant receives adequate lighting for continued healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lycopodium clavatum is generally not necessary as these plants grow quite slowly and maintain a compact shape. However, you can trim dead or damaged sections to promote healthier growth and maintain its appearance. Use sharp, sterilized scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts and prevent infection. If the plant becomes too dense, you can thin it out by cutting select stems at the base, which will improve air circulation and reduce the risk of fungal diseases. Be careful to avoid excessive trimming, as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"stag's-horn clubmoss","description":"Lycopodium clavatum (stag's-horn clubmoss, running clubmoss, or ground pine) is the most widespread species in the genus Lycopodium in the clubmoss family.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["stag's-horn clubmoss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Lycopodium clavatum"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, typically spring through early summer, maintain consistent moisture but never soggy conditions. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Paeonia brownii prefers a location that receives full sun to partial shade. However, in regions with extremely hot summers or intense afternoon sun, some light afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. The plants can tolerate partial shade conditions, but insufficient sunlight may result in reduced vigor and fewer blooms. Always choose a spot with good air circulation to prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Paeonia brownii is generally minimal. After the flowering period, usually in late spring to early summer, remove spent blooms to encourage healthier growth and prevent seed formation that can sap the plant's energy. Trim back any dead or damaged foliage throughout the growing season. In autumn, after the foliage has died back naturally, cut the plant down to near ground level to prepare it for winter dormancy. This helps to prevent disease and tidy up the garden space."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brown's Peony","description":"Paeonia brownii is a low to medium height, herbaceous perennial flowering plant in the family Paeoniaceae. It has compound, steely-gray, somewhat fleshy leaves and small drooping maroon flowers. Its vernacular name is Brown's peony, native peony or western peony. It is native to the western United States and usually grows at altitude, often as undergrowth in part-shade. The fleshy roots store food to carry the plant through the dry summers and produce new leaves and flowers...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["Brown's Peony"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Paeonia brownii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the site has enough space for the tree to grow to its full size without competing for sunlight, as they can reach large dimensions, impacting the light available to the canopy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning pecan trees is essential for maintaining their health and maximizing nut production. Prune during the dormant season, typically in late winter. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration within the canopy. Do not over-prune; removing too much can stress the tree and reduce nut production. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12198,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Amanita citrina, commonly known as the false death cap, is a type of fungus that grows in the wild and does not require traditional plant care, as it is not cultivated like a houseplant or garden flower. With no need for external watering, it relies on the natural humidity and precipitation in its native habitat. If you're studying or observing this fungus in the wild, ensure not to disturb its natural moisture sources."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Amanita citrina typically grows in shaded, forested environments and does not need direct sunlight, unlike many cultivated plants. It thrives in dappled sunlight or even in full shade, where it forms symbiotic relationships with trees. The canopy of the forest provides the right balance of indirect light and protection from harsh sunlight. If found in its natural habitat, ensure it remains in such conditions to support its growth and ecological function, as artificially altering its environment is not necessary or advisable."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a wild-growing fungus, Amanita citrina does not require pruning in the conventional sense. Fungi generally do not have the same pruning needs as plants that homeowners cultivate in gardens or indoors. Instead, it grows and decomposes naturally without intervention. If observing Amanita citrina in a natural setting, it is best to leave it undisturbed to contribute to its ecological role in the forest ecosystem. Removing or cutting mushrooms in the wild can disrupt local biodiversity and ecological balance."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"False Death-cap","description":"Known as the false death cap, or Citron Amanita, Amanita citrina (previously also known as Amanita mappa), is a basidiomycotic mushroom, one of many in the genus Amanita. It grows in silicate soil in the summer and autumn months. It bears a pale yellow or sometimes white cap, with white stem, ring and volva. Though it is not poisonous, its similarity to the lethal death cap (Amanita phalloides) precludes its use in cooking.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["False Death-cap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Amanita citrina"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During dry periods, especially in the growing season from spring to early autumn, ensure it receives approximately one inch of water per week, either from rainfall or manual watering. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture. It's crucial to adapt your watering schedule depending on the local climate and rainfall, making sure the soil is allowed to almost dry out slightly between waterings for optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trifolium medium thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. In particularly hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect it from overheating and wilting. Full sunlight ensures robust health and vibrant blooms, while partial shade can be tolerated but may result in fewer flowers. When planting, choose a spot that balances these conditions, considering nearby structures or trees that may cast shadows at different times of the day. This careful placement ensures the plant receives adequate sunlight throughout its active growth period."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Trifolium medium is relatively straightforward. It benefits from regular trimming to maintain its shape and to encourage bushier growth. After it blooms, typically in late summer, trim back spent flower heads to promote more vigorous flowering the following year and to prevent self-seeding if you wish to control its spread. Generally, cut back the plant by about a third to half its size if it becomes too straggly. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease and damage to the plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13987,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Diospyros kaki, commonly known as the Japanese persimmon, requires consistent watering, especially during the growing season. Ensure the soil is kept moderately moist but not waterlogged. Young trees need more frequent watering than mature trees. During the summer months, thorough watering once a week is generally sufficient, though in extremely dry conditions, you might need to water more frequently. In contrast, reduce watering in the fall to help the plant transition into dormancy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so let the soil dry out slightly between waterings, particularly in the cooler months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Diospyros kaki prefers full sun to produce the best fruit and maintain a healthy structure. Ideally, it should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, less sunlight might reduce fruit production and lead to leggy growth. Ensure the chosen planting spot is not shaded by nearby trees or structures. Full sun exposure helps in enhancing the color and sugar content of the persimmons, providing a healthier tree with better fruiting capability. Ensure the site also has good air circulation to prevent mildew and other diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Diospyros kaki is best done in the late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the tree's health. Additionally, thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation, which can help prevent diseases. Aim to maintain an open structure that allows sunlight to penetrate the tree. If the tree is becoming too tall or wide for your space, you can also trim back some growth to manage its size, ensuring to make clean cuts just above a bud or side branch."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese Persimmon","description":"Diospyros kaki, also called persimmon, is the most widely cultivated species of the genus Diospyros. Although its first published botanical description was not until 1780, the kaki is among the oldest plants in cultivation, known for its use in China for more than 2000 years. In some rural Chinese communities, the kaki fruit is seen as having a great mystical power that can be harnessed to solve headaches, back pains and foot ache.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan"],"other_name":["Japanese Persimmon"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Anthracnose","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Diospyros kaki"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

A balance of direct sun with some afternoon shade can optimize growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lycopus uniflorus is minimal; however, occasional trimming may be beneficial to maintain its shape and encourage dense growth. Reduce watering after flowering as they enter dormancy, stopping completely once the foliage dies back to avoid rotting the bulbs. In fall and winter, if the soil is naturally dry, a light watering may be beneficial, but typically rainwater is sufficient. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent bulb rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Muscari neglectum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. While it can tolerate some shade, exposure to full sunlight leads to more prolific blooming and robust growth. Ideally, these plants should receive at least six hours of sunlight daily. In hotter climates, partial afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent excessive moisture loss. In shaded areas, flowering may be reduced, and plants may become leggy. Plant them in a location that offers adequate sunlight for the best display of their attractive blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Muscari neglectum by removing spent flowers after the blooming period to prevent them from forming seeds and to encourage the plant to direct energy towards bulb strengthening. The foliage should not be cut back while still green, as it provides essential nourishment to the bulbs for the next growing season. Once the foliage turns yellow and withers naturally, it can be removed. This cleanup helps maintain a neat appearance and reduce the chances of pest infestations."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Grape hyacinth","description":"Muscari neglectum is a perennial bulbous plant, one of a number of species and genera known as grape hyacinth and in particular common grape hyacinth or starch grape hyacinth. Muscari are perennial bulbous plants native to Eurasia. They produce spikes of dense, commonly blue, urn-shaped flowers. It is sometimes grown as an ornamental plant, for example, in temperate climates as a spring bulb.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern Europe","Southwest Asia"],"other_name":["Grape hyacinth"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulbs"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Muscari neglectum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12292,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhus ovata, commonly known as Sugar Bush, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. During the first year, water it moderately to help the root system develop. After that, it typically needs watering only during prolonged dry periods. In sandy soil, water every couple of weeks during the summer, ensuring the soil dries out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is crucial to let the soil almost completely dry out between watering sessions. It thrives best with deep, infrequent watering mimicking natural precipitation patterns."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhus ovata thrives in full sun conditions but can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to promote healthy growth and vibrant foliage. While it can survive in environments with some shade, insufficient sunlight may reduce its flowering and overall vigor. Planting it in a sunny location will ensure it develops the characteristic dense, rounded form. When grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window to ensure it gets enough light, rotating the plant occasionally to maintain even growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhus ovata is not always necessary but can be beneficial to maintain shape and remove any dead or damaged branches. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring when the shrub is dormant. Use clean, sharp shears to make cuts at a 45-degree angle to promote healing. Trim back overgrown areas to encourage a bushier appearance and to stimulate healthy growth. Avoid extensive pruning, as this can stress the plant. Regularly clean up fallen leaves and debris from around the plant to minimize disease risk related to poor air circulation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"sugar bush","description":"Rhus ovata, also known as sugar sumac or sugar bush, is an evergreen shrub to small tree that grows in chaparral in dry canyons and south-facing slopes below 1300 m in Southern California, Arizona and Baja California.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["sugar bush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Rhus ovata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13689,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tetraneuris acaulis, commonly known as Stemless Four-Nerve Daisy, prefers well-drained soil and is drought-tolerant once established. Watering should be infrequent, about every two to three weeks during its growing season in spring and fall. Ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. In cooler seasons, especially winter, reduce watering further or withhold altogether if the soil stays moist. Over-watering can harm the plant, so it's crucial to observe the soil moisture rather than sticking to a strict schedule."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tetraneuris acaulis thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. It is well-suited for sunny rock gardens, dry meadows, and xeriscape landscapes. If grown in partial shade, it may not blossom as prolifically, and too much shade can lead to leggy growth. Ensure the plant is situated in an area where it receives ample sunlight to encourage healthy growth and vibrant flowering. It's adapted to open, sunny habitats and performs best under such conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tetraneuris acaulis involves deadheading or cutting back spent flowers to promote continued blooming and maintain the plant's neat appearance. This should be done during its blooming period, typically spring to early summer. Cut the flower stems back to the base without damaging the foliage. After the blooming season, you can also remove any dead or damaged leaves. It doesn't require heavy pruning, as this could stress the plant, and it generally maintains a compact growth habit."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Stemless Four-nerved Daisy","description":"Tetraneuris acaulis is a North American species of flowering plants in the sunflower family. Common names include angelita daisy, stemless four-nerve daisy, stemless hymenoxys, butte marigold, and stemless rubberweed.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Stemless Four-nerved Daisy"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Tetraneuris acaulis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13792,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hypoxis hirsuta, commonly known as the yellow star grass, prefers moderate watering. It is crucial to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during the growing season in spring and early summer. However, it’s important to avoid waterlogging, as excess moisture can lead to root rot. In fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Using a well-draining soil mix can aid in preventing excess moisture retention. Be vigilant about the plant’s needs as they might vary depending on environmental conditions such as humidity and temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypoxis hirsuta thrives in full to partial sunlight. It prefers a spot where it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of bright, direct sunlight per day. If grown in extremely hot regions, providing afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. While it can tolerate some degree of shade, insufficient light might hinder flowering. Position it in a location where it can bask in the gentle morning sun. Monitoring the plant’s response to light conditions is key, as too much intense sun can lead to withering while too little may reduce flower production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hypoxis hirsuta is relatively straightforward, as this plant does not require extensive pruning. The main task is to remove dead or damaged leaves and spent flower stalks to maintain its appearance and prevent diseases. This can be done throughout the growing season as needed. You can pinch off dead flower heads once they begin to wither to encourage neatness and potentially spur another bloom. Ensure your pruning tools are clean and sharp to avoid any plant damage or disease transmission. Remember to handle the plant gently as the leaves can be somewhat delicate."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"yellow star grass","description":"Hypoxis hirsuta (common goldstar, common star-grass, eastern yellow stargrass, yellow star grass) is an ornamental plant in the Hypoxidaceae family. Sometimes this plant is placed in the Amaryllidaceae family or the Liliaceae family. The species is native to the United States, Canada, and the State of Tamaulipas in northeastern Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["yellow star grass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Hypoxis hirsuta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12393,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Flammulina velutipes, commonly known as the enoki mushroom, is usually grown in specific, controlled environments. Proper moisture is crucial for its growth, with a preference for damp, cool conditions. If cultivating enoki mushrooms at home or in a controlled environment, maintaining high humidity levels is essential. This typically involves keeping the growing medium, such as sawdust, consistently moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering can lead to mold and bacterial growth, which can be detrimental to the mushrooms. Using a misting system or humidity tent can help maintain the appropriate moisture levels, ensuring healthy mushroom development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Flammulina velutipes, unlike many plants, does not require direct sunlight. In fact, enoki mushrooms prefer to grow in dark conditions, mimicking their natural environment under tree bark or in shaded woods. For indoor cultivation, they should be kept in low light conditions or complete darkness for more traditional varieties. If using artificial grow lights, ensure they emit minimal heat and are not too intense, as strong light can adversely affect mushroom development. The goal is to simulate a cool, dark environment, which promotes the characteristic long stems and small caps of enoki mushrooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not traditionally required for the cultivation of Flammulina velutipes as it is a mushroom species. Instead, it is harvested once the mushrooms reach the desired size, usually when the caps are partially expanded but not fully opened. To \"prune\" or harvest, use a sharp knife to cut the mushrooms at the base of the stem. Regular harvesting encourages healthy growth of subsequent flushes, and maintaining clean and sanitary growing conditions helps prevent contamination. Removing any dead or overly mature mushrooms promptly is also recommended to maintain the health of the mycelium bed."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Velvet Foot","description":"Enokitake (榎茸, エノキタケ, Japanese pronunciation: , /ɪˌnoʊkiˈtɑːkiː/), also Enokidake (榎茸, エノキダケ, Japanese pronunciation: , /ɪˌnoʊkiˈdɑːkiː/) or Enoki (榎, エノキ, Japanese pronunciation: , /ɪˈnoʊki/), is a long, thin white mushroom used in East Asian cuisine (such as that of China, Japan, Vietnam and Korea). These mushrooms are cultivars of Flammulina velutipes, also known by the name golden needle mushroom or lily mushroom. Wild forms differing in color, texture, and sliminess are called names including seafood mushrooms, winter mushrooms or winter...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Winter","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["East Asia"],"other_name":["Velvet Foot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation","Substrate Culture"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Flammulina velutipes"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Rich organic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Typically, watering once every two to three weeks during the growing season should suffice, reducing to once a month or less during the dormant season. If grown in partial shade, it may become leggy or produce fewer flowers. Ensuring the plant receives adequate sunlight will help it thrive and showcase its best appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Palafoxia arida is not typically necessary for its health but can be done to maintain shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins, or after the blooming period. Trim back any dead or damaged stems, and consider removing up to a third of the plant to invigorate new growth. Removing spent flowers can also promote additional flowering, but be cautious not to cut into the older woody parts of the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Spanish needle","description":"Palafoxia arida is a species of flowering plant in the aster family, known by the common names desert palafox and Spanish needle.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Spanish needle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Palafoxia arida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13093,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eurybia integrifolia, commonly known as entire-leaved aster, prefers regular watering to thrive. It is important to maintain evenly moist soil, especially during the growing season, but it's crucial to avoid waterlogging as this can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to ensure the roots are not sitting in water. In particularly hot climates or during dry spells, more frequent watering might be necessary. Using mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering required."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eurybia integrifolia thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It is adaptable but performs optimally with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to encourage maximum flowering. In regions with scorching afternoon heat, providing partial shade during those intense hours can help prevent scorching of leaves. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Ideal planting locations are where the plant receives morning sun and some afternoon shade, ensuring a balanced environment for robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eurybia integrifolia involves removing dead or damaged stems and flowers to maintain its health and aesthetics. This can be done in early spring to encourage new growth and maintain plant shape. After the plant blooms, deadhead spent flowers to prevent the plant from going to seed and to encourage a longer blooming period. Cut back the entire plant to the ground in late fall or early winter after the foliage has died back to help the plant direct energy towards root development and prepare for a vigorous spring regrowth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"thickstem aster","description":"Eurybia integrifolia, (formerly Aster integrifolius) commonly called the thickstem aster, is an herbaceous perennial in the composite family. It is native to the western United States where it grows primarily in the Rocky Mountains, the Great Basin, and the Sierra Nevada in Washington, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Utah, Oregon, Nevada, and California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["thickstem aster"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Eurybia integrifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14079,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lathyrus linifolius, commonly known as bitter vetch or heath pea, requires moderate watering. During its growing season, keep the soil consistently moist but never waterlogged. The plant prefers well-draining soil to prevent root rot. In the dormant season, reduce watering frequency significantly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Always check the top layer of the soil before watering to ensure it isn't still damp, as overwatering can be detrimental to the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lathyrus linifolius thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day, especially during its active growth and flowering seasons. If located in a region with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat and prevent wilting. In areas where sunlight is less intense, ensuring exposure to morning sunlight can be beneficial for optimal growth. Proper sunlight exposure is crucial for the plant's health and flowering performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lathyrus linifolius is relatively straightforward and involves primarily removal of dead stems and foliage to encourage healthy growth. It's best to avoid cutting more than one-third of the plant's height at a time to minimize stress. Protection from intense light will help maintain a suitable environment for the health of the fungus."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a fungus, Amanita rubescens does not require pruning. Fungi do not grow in the same manner as plants and therefore do not benefit from pruning. If growing in artificial conditions, simple removal of any deteriorating or spore-discharged mushrooms is sufficient to maintain a clean environment for further fungal growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"blusher","description":"The blusher is the common name for several closely related species of the genus Amanita. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13394,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pancratium maritimum, commonly known as the sea daffodil, is a plant that's naturally adapted to sandy and well-drained soils often found in coastal environments. It requires minimal watering once established. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to bulb rot. During its growing season, which typically coincides with hotter months, moderate watering is recommended to keep the soil slightly moist. In its dormant phase, reduce watering significantly, maintaining just enough moisture to prevent the bulbs from desiccating. Mimicking its natural arid habitat conditions is key to its successful cultivation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pancratium maritimum thrives in full sunlight, reflecting its natural habitat along sunny, sandy beaches of the Mediterranean. It should be planted in a location where it can receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate some light shade, optimal flowering occurs when exposed to abundant sunlight. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a south-facing window can help provide the necessary light intensity. Ensuring sufficient sunlight is critical for its blooming cycle and overall health, simulating its native sun-drenched environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pancratium maritimum is minimal and primarily involves removing spent flowers and yellowing leaves to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. Deadheading the flowers once they have faded helps the plant direct its energy toward bulb development rather than seed production. Leaves naturally die back in the fall; they should be allowed to wither fully before removal as they provide nutrients back to the bulbs. Maintaining cleanliness around the plant by removing debris can also help prevent potential pest and fungal problems."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sea Daffodil","description":"Pancratium maritimum, or sea daffodil, is a species of bulbous plant native to the Canary Islands and both sides of the Mediterranean region and Black Sea from Portugal, Morocco and the Balearic Islands east to Turkey, Syria, Israel and the Caucasus. In the parts of its range on the south Bulgarian and north Turkish and Georgian coasts of Black Sea, it is threatened with extinction. It is also naturalized in southern California, Bermuda and the Azores.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean Basin","Europe","North Africa","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Sea Daffodil"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pancratium maritimum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12794,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Buddleja saligna, or the False Olive, is relatively drought-tolerant once established, meaning it does not require frequent watering. However, during its establishment phase, particularly in the first year, it should be watered regularly to encourage root growth. Water deeply but allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During hot, dry weather, occasional deep waterings will help the plant thrive. Reducing watering frequency in cooler months is advisable, as plant growth slows down and excess moisture can be detrimental."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Buddleja saligna thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. However, it can also tolerate partial shade, though this may result in fewer flowers. The more sun the plant receives, the more robust its blooming. In extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat stress, but generally, planting in a location with ample sunlight exposure is ideal for healthy growth and vibrant flowering of the False Olive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Buddleja saligna is essential to maintain its shape and promote flowering. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring, just before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or crossed branches to keep the plant healthy. Then, prune back up to one-third of the plant's overall size to encourage bushier growth and more prolific blooming. Regular pruning also helps to prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. Being a fast grower, light pruning throughout the growing season can maintain an attractive shape."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"False Olive","description":"Buddleja saligna, the false, or bastard, olive, is almost endemic to South Africa where it has a wide distribution. It occurs most often in ravines and against outcrops, and is distributed from coastal elevations to the central plateau at elevations of < 2000 m. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14080,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salix aurita, commonly known as the eared willow, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. It is important to water it regularly, especially during dry spells or if it is planted in a container. The soil should not be allowed to dry out completely, as willows prefer to have access to steady moisture. Monitor the soil moisture by checking the top few inches of the soil, ensuring it remains damp but not waterlogged, which can lead to root rot and other issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salix aurita thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It requires at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight a day, which helps it grow strong and healthy. While it can tolerate some shade, too little sunlight may lead to reduced growth and a sparser form. Plant it in a location where it can receive morning sun with some afternoon shade if the climate is particularly hot, as this can help prevent leaf scorch and ensure the best overall growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salix aurita is essential to maintain its shape and health. It is best to prune these shrubs in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to promote healthy growth and increase air circulation within the plant. Additionally, cutting back old wood can encourage the plant to produce new shoots, which can be more aesthetically pleasing. It has hairy stems, is either prostrate or ascending, with dark green leaves that are one of petiolate, crenate, toothed, rounded, or oval. All flowers are small and bright blue. It is best to prune the plant during its active growing season. Regularly remove spent flowers to encourage continued blooming. Trim back any leggy or overly long stems to maintain the desired shape and size of the plant. Cut back damaged or dead stems to prevent potential diseases. A light trim during late winter or early spring can help stimulate new growth and keep the plant looking tidy and healthy throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Indian Heliotrope","description":"Heliotropium indicum, commonly known as Indian heliotrope, is an annual, hirsute plant that is a common weed in waste places and settled areas. When choosing a planting location, aim for an area with morning sun exposure and protection from the harshest afternoon rays. Regular monitoring of its light conditions can help ensure this woody shrub gets the sunlight it needs without undue stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viburnum rufidulum is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus initially on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health. Thinning out crowded areas helps to increase air circulation and light penetration, promoting better growth. Shape the plant to your liking by cutting back overgrown or wayward branches. However, avoid heavy pruning as this can impact the plant's flowering capabilities for the coming season. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14081,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gyromitra esculenta, commonly known as a false morel, is not a plant but a type of fungus. In its natural habitat, it appears in sandy soils typically in pine forests during spring. Cultivating this fungus is not a typical activity like with garden plants, but ensuring adequate moisture can be beneficial if attempting to grow for research or personal interest. Outdoor conditions such as natural rainfall usually suffice, but misting the area can be considered during dry spells. Water thoroughly but ensure the substrate isn't waterlogged to avoid damaging the fungal growth environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gyromitra esculenta, or false morels, are fungi that grow in shaded, forested areas, typically under conifer trees during spring. Unlike green plants, they do not require sunlight for photosynthesis, but they thrive in the natural forest lighting, which provides a mix of dappled light and ample shade. When attempting to culture them or replicate their habitat, it's important to simulate these conditions with indirect light and lots of shade. Avoid direct sunlight as it can dry out the fungi and the substrate they grow on, potentially hindering growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Since Gyromitra esculenta is a type of fungus and not a traditional plant, the concept of pruning does not apply. Fungi do not have branches or leaves that require trimming. However, when harvesting, it is important to handle the fungi gently to avoid damage to the mycelium—the underground network that supports its growth. Use a clean, sharp knife to cut the fruiting body at its base, leaving the substrate intact to encourage future growth. Always harvest responsibly and ensure correct identification due to potential toxicity."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"False Morel","description":"Gyromitra esculenta /ˌdʒaɪroʊˈmaɪtrə ˌɛskjəˈlɛntə, ˌdʒɪrə-/, is an ascomycete fungus from the genus Gyromitra, widely distributed across Europe and North America. It normally fruits in sandy soils under coniferous trees in spring and early summer. The fruiting body, or mushroom, is an irregular brain-shaped cap dark brown in colour that can reach 10 cm (4 in) high and 15 cm (6 in) wide, perched on a stout white stipe up to 6 cm (2.4 in) high.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["False Morel"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Gyromitra esculenta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13492,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Poa nemoralis, commonly known as wood bluegrass, has moderate watering needs. It prefers evenly moist soil, especially during establishment. However, once established, it is somewhat drought tolerant. The key is to ensure the soil doesn't dry out completely, as it thrives in cool, moist environments. Frequent light watering is more beneficial than infrequent deep watering, especially in well-draining soil. Avoid waterlogged conditions as this can lead to root rot. Monitor the soil moisture regularly, and adjust the watering schedule during dry or particularly warm periods to maintain healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Poa nemoralis thrives best in partial to full shade, making it ideal for areas where many grasses may not perform well. It is adapted to woodland conditions, so it doesn't require direct sunlight and can grow under the canopy of trees or in shaded garden areas. Exposure to too much direct sunlight can cause stress, leading to browning or drying out of the grass. Ideally, provide it with dappled light or the type of indirect light found in its native woodland habitats, ensuring it receives some protection from harsh, midday sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Poa nemoralis typically involves removing old or dead growth to encourage new, healthy shoots. It doesn't require extensive pruning; instead, you can focus on maintaining its shape and preventing it from becoming too untidy. Early spring is a good time to trim back any spent growth from the previous year before new growth begins. Occasional trimming can also help prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. If used as a ground cover, mowing it at a high setting can be a simple way of keeping it neat and promoting vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wood Meadow-grass","description":"Poa nemoralis, the wood bluegrass, is a perennial plant in the Poaceae family. The late-growing grass is fairly nutritious for livestock, which feed on it in the autumn.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Wood Meadow-grass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Poa nemoralis"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13691,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thalictrum occidentale, also known as Western Meadow-rue, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. Water the plant deeply once a week if there is no rain, but be cautious of overwatering, as it does not tolerate waterlogged conditions. During extremely hot or dry spells, increase the frequency of watering slightly. In the dormancy period over winter, reduce watering significantly to allow the soil to dry out more between sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thalictrum occidentale thrives best in partial shade to full sun environments. It prefers morning sun and afternoon shade in hotter climates, as too much direct, intense sunlight can scorch the leaves. In cooler climates, it can tolerate more direct sun exposure. Ideally, plant it in a location where it receives bright, filtered light for most of the day, ensuring it gets at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight. Insufficient light may lead to weak, leggy growth and reduced flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Thalictrum occidentale involves cutting back the plant after flowering to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Once the blooming period is over, typically in late summer, remove any spent flowers and dead stems to prevent disease and encourage new growth. In late autumn or early spring, trim back the stems to ground level to make way for fresh growth. Regularly check and remove any damaged or diseased leaves or stems throughout the growing season to support robust plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Meadow-rue","description":"Thalictrum occidentale is a species of flowering plant in the buttercup family known by the common name western meadow-rue. This preference for full sun makes it ideal for rock gardens and open fields."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Machaeranthera tanacetifolia is seldom necessary as the plant naturally maintains a tidy growth habit. However, removing spent blooms during the growing season encourages more blooms and prolongs the flowering period. At the end of the flowering season, you can cut the plant back to manage its spread and prevent it from becoming scraggly. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and reduce the risk of disease. Minimal pruning helps maintain the plant's natural look."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Tahoka daisy","description":"Machaeranthera tanacetifolia is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common names tansyleaf tansyaster and Tahoka daisy. It is an annual or biennial herb growing one or more branching stems up to about 70 centimetres (28 in) in maximum height. The multilobed leaves are up to 12 centimetres (4 3⁄4 in) long. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12894,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cinnamomum camphora, commonly known as the camphor tree, prefers well-drained soil and should be watered regularly during its growing season. This plant thrives when the soil is kept consistently moist, but not waterlogged. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering frequency, allowing the soil top few inches to dry out between watering, to prevent root rot. In general, a deep watering every 7 to 10 days is recommended in hotter climates, while a smaller watering frequency is suitable in cooler temperatures. Always consider the rainfall in your area to adjust the watering schedule accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cinnamomum camphora thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, aim to provide it with at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day for optimal growth and health. Full sun exposure ensures the tree develops a robust and well-structured canopy. However, in hotter climates, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent scorching and stress on the leaves. If growing indoors or in shaded areas, ensure it gets as much indirect bright light as possible to support its photosynthetic needs. Always consider the local climate when deciding the plant's placement regarding sunlight exposure. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cinnamomum camphora helps maintain its shape, and manage its size, and remove any diseased or damaged branches. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Focus first on removing dead, damaged, or crossing branches to promote better air circulation. Next, shape the tree by selectively cutting back to promising outward-facing buds or nodes, which encourages bushier and more controlled growth. Avoid excessive pruning, which can cause stress and reduce the tree's vitality. Regular, light pruning is generally more beneficial than severe pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Camphor Tree","description":"Cinnamomum camphora (commonly known as camphor tree, camphorwood or camphor laurel) is a large evergreen tree that grows up to 20–30 m (66–98 ft) tall. The leaves have a glossy, waxy appearance and smell of camphor when crushed. In spring, it produces bright green foliage with masses of small white flowers. It produces clusters of black, berry-like fruit around 1 cm (0.39 in) in diameter. Its pale bark is very rough and fissured vertically.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan","Taiwan"],"other_name":["Camphor Tree"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cinnamomum camphora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12593,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lavandula dentata, commonly known as French lavender, thrives in well-drained soil and requires moderate watering. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it’s important to let the soil dry out between waterings. During the growing season in spring and summer, water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out slightly before watering again. In autumn and winter, reduce watering, particularly if the plant is grown in cooler climates or indoors, to mimic its natural Mediterranean habitat. Always err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lavandula dentata prefers full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to thrive and bloom profusely. It is well-suited for planting in south or west-facing locations where it can soak up as much light as possible. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little sun may result in fewer flowers and reduced aromatic properties. If grown indoors, place it near a bright, sunny window. In climates with intense afternoon sun, providing slight shade during peak hours can prevent leaf scorching and help maintain optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for Lavandula dentata to promote healthy growth and maintain its shape. The best time to prune is in late summer after the main flowering period. Cut back about a third of the plant’s height, focusing on removing spent flowers and any dead or straggly stems. Avoid cutting into the woody parts of the plant, as lavender does not regrow from old wood. Regular pruning encourages new growth and flowering and helps prevent the plant from becoming leggy. A light trim in early spring can also invigorate the plant before the blooming season begins."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"French lavender","description":"Lavandula dentata, or French lavender, is a species of flowering plant in the Lamiaceae family, native to the Mediterranean, the Atlantic islands and the Arabian peninsula. Growing to 60 cm (24 in) tall, it has gray-green, linear or lance-shaped leaves with toothed edges and a lightly woolly texture. The long-lasting, narrow spikes of purple flowers, topped with pale violet bracts, first appear in late spring. The whole plant is strongly aromatic with the typical lavender fragrance.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["French lavender"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whitefly","Leafhoppers"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lavandula dentata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the flowering period in late spring or early summer, deadhead the flowers to encourage the plant to focus its energy on growth rather than seed production. It requires minimal watering, making it a low-maintenance option for gardens. Water it deeply but infrequently, ensuring the soil is dry between waterings. Overwatering can cause root rot, so it's essential to let the soil dry out completely before the next watering. If grown in pots, ensure there are adequate drainage holes to prevent waterlog. Lack of sufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced vitality, so prioritize a spot with abundant natural light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ditaxis lanceolata should be minimal since it's a hardy plant that often maintains its shape naturally. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13095,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fagonia laevis, commonly known as caltrop or buckbush, is a drought-tolerant plant, which means it requires minimal watering under normal conditions. During the growing season, water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so it's important to err on the side of underwatering with this plant. In winter, especially if the plant is in a colder region or in a dormant state, watering should be reduced significantly, relying more on natural rainfall if possible."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fagonia laevis thrives in full sun to partial shade, making it suitable for areas that receive ample sunlight throughout the day. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure healthy growth and flowering. Regular pruning can also help promote bushier growth. The best time to prune is during the dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. In addition, remove any spent flowers to encourage new blooms and prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production unless propagation is desired."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"California fagonbush","description":"Fagonia laevis, the California fagonbush, is a species of plant in the Zygophyllaceae, the caltrop family. A good rule of thumb is to let the soil dry out between waterings, mimicking its natural preference for drier conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Panicum capillare thrives in full sun, preferring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. If grown in partial shade, the plant might not perform as vigorously, affecting overall aesthetic appeal. When choosing a planting location, opt for an area with maximum sunlight to match its natural habitat and to help the plant develop dense, lush foliage and sturdy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Witchgrass typically requires minimal pruning since it is a grass species that naturally maintains its shape. However, you may choose to prune to remove dead or damaged stalks to promote healthy growth and to maintain a tidy appearance. Pruning can be done at any time when the plant appears overgrown or when you notice dead foliage. It's typically best to prune at the end of the growing season, cutting back the stalks to just above ground level to encourage fresh growth in the coming season. Use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"witch grass","description":"Panicum capillare, known by the common name witchgrass, is a species of grass. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12395,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Darmera peltata, commonly known as the umbrella plant, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. Water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil does not dry out, which is critical for sustaining its lush foliage. However, avoid waterlogging, which can cause root rot. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering but ensure the soil remains slightly moist, providing just enough water to prevent it from becoming completely dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Darmera peltata grows best in partial to full shade. It can tolerate some dappled sunlight, especially in cooler climates, but thrives in environments where it is protected from intense afternoon sun, which can scorch its large leaves. If planted in an area with some sun exposure, morning light is preferable as it is less intense. Ideal locations include shaded gardens or areas near water bodies where taller plants or structures provide natural protection from excessive sunlight, ensuring the plant remains lush and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Darmera peltata in late fall or early spring, once the leaves have died back or before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged leaves by cutting them at their base to maintain the plant's appearance and health. This plant does not require heavy pruning; focus on cleaning up the plant to prevent disease and promote tidy growth. Monitoring and removing faded flowers and spent stems will also encourage vigorous growth and maintain the plant's aesthetic appeal, ensuring it thrives throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Umbrella Plant","description":"Darmera peltata (Indian rhubarb or umbrella plant) is a flowering plant, the only species within the genus Darmera in the family Saxifragaceae. It is a slowly spreading rhizomatous perennial native to mountain streamsides in woodland in the western United States (southwestern Oregon to northwestern California), growing to 2 m (6 ft 7 in) tall by 1 m (3 ft 3 in) wide. The name Darmera comes after Karl Darmer, a Berlin horticulturist from 19th century.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Umbrella Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Darmera peltata"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12294,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ceanothus spinosus, also known as the Greenbark Ceanothus, is drought-tolerant once established, so it prefers infrequent deep watering. During its first year, water it deeply once a week to help it develop a strong root system. After establishment, usually by the second or third year, reduce watering to once every two to three weeks in the summer and less often during cooler months. Always allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot. It's essential to ensure good drainage to mimic its native conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ceanothus spinosus thrives in full sun conditions, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. It can tolerate some light shade but flowering may be reduced. Plant it in a location that receives ample sunlight to ensure it blooms vigorously and maintains its health. Protection from intense afternoon sun in extremely hot climates can help prevent heat stress. Aim to place this plant where it can bask in morning and early afternoon sunlight for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ceanothus spinosus should be done sparingly, as these plants prefer minimal interference. The best time to prune is right after the flowering period in late spring or early summer. Remove any dead or damaged wood and, for shaping, trim branches just above a leaf node to encourage bushier growth. Avoid heavy pruning into old wood, as this can inhibit regrowth. Prune lightly each year to maintain a manageable shape and size, keeping in mind the natural growth habit of this attractive shrub."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"greenbark ceanothus","description":"Ceanothus spinosus, with the common names greenbark and redheart, is a species of Ceanothus. It is native to southern California and northern Baja California, where it grows in the scrub and chaparral of the coastal mountain ranges.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["greenbark ceanothus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf rollers"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Ceanothus spinosus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12795,"attracts":["Fish","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cabomba caroliniana, commonly known as Carolina Fanwort, requires consistent moisture as it is an aquatic plant. It thrives in soft, acidic water and should be fully submerged in the aquarium or pond environment. Ensure that the water maintains a stable temperature between 15-28 degrees Celsius. Avoid using hard water as it can hinder the plant's growth. Regular water changes in aquariums will help maintain the necessary water parameters. It's important to avoid allowing the water to become too stagnant, as this can negatively affect the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cabomba caroliniana prefers moderate to high light environments. In aquariums, it is best suited under full spectrum lighting, which can mimic sunlight and support its photosynthesis process. Natural sunlight can be beneficial for pond settings but ensure it's not exposed to direct, harsh sunlight for prolonged periods as this could lead to temperature fluctuations in the water. Typically, 8-12 hours of lighting per day will suffice in an aquarium setup. Insufficient lighting can lead to poor growth and leaf shedding."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning of Cabomba caroliniana is important to maintain its shape and control its rapid growth. Trim back the longer stems to encourage a bushier appearance and to prevent it from overshadowing other plants. Use sharp, sterilized scissors to cut back any dead or decaying stems or leaves. Pruning should be done delicately, as Cabomba can be quite fragile. Moreover, removing excess growth helps maintain optimal water flow and light penetration in the aquarium or pond environment."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Carolina Fanwort","description":"Cabomba caroliniana is an aquatic perennial herbaceous plant native to North and South America. It is a weed of national significance in Australia and on the list of invasive alien species of union concern in the EU.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["Carolina Fanwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Snails"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cabomba caroliniana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Nutrient-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
