{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13990,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rubus rosifolius, commonly known as the roseleaf bramble, thrives in moist but well-draining soil. It is crucial to maintain consistent soil moisture, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. Ideally, water the plant once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch; this can be approximately once or twice a week depending on the climate and weather conditions. Avoid waterlogging or allowing the roots to sit in standing water, as this can lead to root rot. During the dormant season in the winter, reduce watering frequency to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus rosifolius requires plenty of sunlight to flourish. Ideally, it should be placed in a location that receives full sun, which means at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with very hot summers, providing the plant with partial shade during the hottest part of the day can prevent leaf scorch and dehydration. Insufficient sunlight may lead to reduced fruit production and stunted growth, so ensure the plant is receiving adequate light depending on your local climate conditions. Regular assessment of the plant's light exposure can ensure optimal health and productivity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus rosifolius is essential for promoting healthy growth and encouraging fruit production. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased canes at their base to improve air circulation and prevent diseases. After fruiting, remove the old canes that produced fruit as these will not fruit again. Thin out canes to allow sunlight to permeate the plant, focusing on removing the weakest canes while keeping 4-6 of the healthiest canes. Regular pruning promotes a more vigorous and productive plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"roseleaf bramble","description":"Rubus rosifolius, (sometimes spelled Rubus rosaefolius), also known as roseleaf bramble, Mauritius raspberry, thimbleberry Vanuatu raspberry and bramble of the Cape is a prickly subshrub native to rainforest and tall open forest of the Himalayas, East Asia, and eastern Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","Asia"],"other_name":["roseleaf bramble"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Fungal infections"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rubus rosifolius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12494,"attracts":["Fish","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Azolla caroliniana, also known as Carolina Mosquito Fern, requires consistent moisture as it thrives in wet conditions. In drier conditions or when grown in non-pond settings, make sure to mist regularly or keep the container in a water dish to maintain humidity and prevent drying out. It's important to avoid drying out at any time, as this plant is not drought-tolerant and requires moisture to survive."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Azolla caroliniana prefers bright conditions and ideally should be placed where it can receive partial sunlight for several hours daily. Full sun can be tolerated but may cause scorching if the water is too shallow and heats up, or if it is exposed to intense, direct sunlight for prolonged periods, especially in hotter climates. Providing some shade during the hottest part of the day can help maintain a healthy growing environment. If the plant is in a pond or another water body, natural filtering of the light through the water can also assist in preventing burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Azolla caroliniana is generally not necessary unless it is being grown in constrained spaces or needs to be controlled. It's beneficial to deadhead the plant regularly by removing spent flowers, which promotes continued blooming. In early spring, before new growth begins, perform a hard prune by cutting back the previous season’s growth to about 6 inches above the ground. This helps to maintain a sturdy structure and encourages dense, bushy growth. Avoid pruning in late fall to help the plant recover naturally and leave some stems for winter interest."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"nettle-leaf giant hyssop","description":"Agastache urticifolia is a species of flowering plant in the mint family known by the common name nettleleaf giant hyssop or horse mint. At the end of the growing season, cut back the entire plant to a few inches above the ground to prepare it for new growth in spring. Overall, pruning helps maintain an attractive shape and reduces the likelihood of disease by improving air circulation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"pot marigold","description":"Calendula officinalis, the pot marigold, ruddles, common marigold or Scotch marigold, is a plant in the genus Calendula of the family Asteraceae. During the plant's active growing period in spring, it requires regular watering, particularly in periods of drought, to ensure the soil remains evenly moist. However, it's important not to overwater, as the plant can be susceptible to root rot if left in waterlogged conditions. In summer and fall, reduce the frequency of watering once the blooms have faded, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings, which helps maintain healthy roots and prevents disease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox subulata thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce vibrant blooms. Planting it in a sunny location ensures the foliage remains dense and colorful, and it also helps prevent issues with mildew, a common problem for phlox grown in less-than-ideal light conditions. In regions with very hot summers, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to protect the plant from scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox subulata involves trimming back the foliage and deadheading spent blooms to promote bushier growth and encourage a second wave of flowering. After the main blooming season in late spring, cut back the stems by about one-third of their length to prevent the plant from becoming leggy and to maintain a compact form. The soil should be kept moist but not waterlogged. It’s important to ensure that the plant does not sit in water as this can lead to root rot. Water the plant once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the growing season, especially in warmer climates, you may need to water more frequently due to increased evaporation. In cooler months or when the plant is dormant, reduce the watering frequency. Always water at the base of the plant to avoid wetting the foliage, which can cause mildew."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Papaver somniferum plants thrive in full sunlight. They require at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. Plant them in an area where they can receive plenty of sun exposure. Too little sunlight can result in weak plants with few blooms. If growing indoors or in a greenhouse, use supplementary grow lights to mimic full sunlight conditions. In extremely hot climates, if the sun is too intense, providing a slight shade during the peak heat of the day can prevent scorching. Ensure the light source is evenly distributed to avoid leggy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Papaver somniferum should focus on removing dead or faded flowers to encourage further blooming and prevent the plant from seeding prematurely. Deadheading should be done regularly by snipping off the spent flowers right at the base of the flower stem. If you wish to collect seeds, allow some flowers to remain and develop seed pods. Also, remove any dead or yellowing leaves to keep the plant healthy and to reduce the risk of disease. Pruning can be done throughout the growing season but is mostly beneficial during the active blooming phase."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"opium poppy","description":"Papaver somniferum, the opium poppy, is a species of flowering plant in the family Papaveraceae. It is the species of plant from which opium and poppy seeds are derived and is a valuable ornamental plant, grown in gardens. Its native range is probably the eastern Mediterranean, but is now obscured by ancient introductions and cultivation.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern Mediterranean","Southern Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["opium poppy"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Papaver somniferum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It thrives in dry, rocky, or sandy environments typical of alpine or tundra regions. Watering should be moderate, ensuring that the soil remains only slightly damp, not soggy, to mimic its natural conditions. It's crucial to allow the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season in the spring and early summer, water adjustments may be necessary, but in winter, watering should be minimal to avoid root rot due to the plant's resting phase."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dryas octopetala thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is adapted to regions with high sunlight exposure, such as alpine and subarctic environments. For optimal growth, ensure the plant receives at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. It can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates, but excessive shade may result in reduced flowering. Its ability to withstand harsh sunlight makes it suitable for rock gardens or areas with well-drained soil where exposure is high. Ensuring adequate sunlight helps encourage dense foliage and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Dryas octopetala is generally minimal. The plant is low-growing, forming a mat, and typically doesn’t require heavy pruning. However, removing dead or damaged stems after flowering can promote healthy growth. Pruning can help maintain the plant’s shape and encourage denser foliage. Trim away any spent flowers to prevent seed formation and help the plant conserve energy. This also aids in keeping the garden tidier. Late fall or early spring is the ideal time for pruning, as it prepares the plant for the upcoming growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Eight-petal Mountain-Avens","description":"Dryas octopetala (common names include mountain avens, eightpetal mountain-avens, white dryas, and white dryad) is an Arctic–alpine flowering plant in the family Rosaceae. It is a small prostrate evergreen subshrub forming large colonies. The specific epithet octopetala derives from the Greek octo (eight) and petalon (petal), referring to the eight petals of the flower, an unusual number in the Rosaceae, where five is the normal number. However, flowers with up to 16 petals also occur naturally.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Arctic","Alpine regions of Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Eight-petal Mountain-Avens"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Dryas octopetala"],"soil":["Gravelly","Well-drained","Loamy Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12897,"attracts":["Bees","Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cirsium neomexicanum typically requires moderate watering. It is important to let the soil dry out slightly between waterings, as this plant is somewhat drought tolerant and too much water can lead to root rot. During the growing season, regular watering is beneficial, especially if the weather is particularly dry. However, during fall and winter, the frequency of watering can be reduced significantly. It's advisable to water early in the day to allow excess water to evaporate, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cirsium neomexicanum thrives in full sunlight, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day to promote healthy growth and vibrant flowering. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, excessive shade can lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. In regions with particularly intense summer sun, some afternoon shade can be beneficial. Placement in an area with good air circulation can also help reduce the risk of fungal diseases often exacerbated by high humidity and poor ventilation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cirsium neomexicanum isn't often necessary, but it can help maintain the plant's shape and encourage healthier growth. Deadheading spent flowers can promote further blooming and help prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. It is also beneficial to remove any dead or damaged leaves and stems to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of fungal diseases. Pruning is best performed in the late winter or early spring while the plant is dormant, using clean, sharp tools to minimize plant stress."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"New Mexico thistle","description":"Cirsium neomexicanum is a North American species of thistle known by the common names New Mexico thistle, powderpuff thistle, lavender thistle, foss thistle and desert thistle.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["New Mexico thistle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cirsium neomexicanum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14084,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Podocarpus totara, commonly known as Totara, prefers well-drained soil and is somewhat drought-tolerant once established. Initially, it should be watered regularly to help the roots establish, especially if planted in dry conditions. However, it is important not to overwater, as excess moisture can lead to root rot. Let the topsoil dry out somewhat between waterings but ensure it does not dry out completely. During hotter months, additional watering may be necessary, but generally, natural rainfall should suffice once established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Totara prefers full sun to light shade for optimal growth. In its native habitat, it thrives under full sun conditions but can tolerate partial shade. When placed in an area with full sun, it grows faster and more robustly, while in shaded areas, growth may be slower with a more open habit. When planting in hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect from extreme heat. Ensure that the Totara receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Totara benefits from pruning to maintain shape and encourage denser foliage. Prune during the late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove dead, damaged, or crossed branches to improve air circulation and maintain the tree’s health. It's also advisable to trim any unwanted vertical growth if a more bushy appearance is desired. Regular light trimming can encourage a more compact form, essential for Totara used as a hedge or screen. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant; instead, make subtle adjustments over time."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tōtara","description":"Podocarpus totara (tōtara) is a species of podocarp tree endemic to New Zealand. It grows throughout the North Island and northeastern South Island in lowland, montane and lower subalpine forest at elevations of up to 600 m.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Tōtara"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Podocarpus totara"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12798,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calliandra eriophylla, commonly known as Fairy Duster, is drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering. During the summer growth period, water deeply once every 2-3 weeks. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the plant. In winter, the plant is dormant and needs even less water. Reduce irrigation to once a month or less during this period. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calliandra eriophylla thrives in full sun, which promotes optimal flowering and growth. It requires a minimum of 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for the best results. If planted in a slightly shaded area, it may not bloom as prolifically and might develop a more leggy appearance. In regions with extreme heat, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent sun scorch. Proper sunlight exposure is essential to maintain its vibrant pink flowers and healthy foliage. Adjust planting locations accordingly for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Calliandra eriophylla should primarily be done in late winter or early spring before the new growth starts. It involves removing dead or damaged branches to maintain plant health and appearance. Light pruning encourages a compact shape and fuller foliage. Using clean, sharp pruning shears, make cuts just above a leaf node or outward-facing bud, and avoid cutting into the older, harder wood. Regular light pruning helps stimulate flowering. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can reduce flowering significantly."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"pink fairy-duster","description":"Calliandra eriophylla, commonly known as fairy duster, is a low spreading shrub which is native to deserts and arid grasslands in California, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas and Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["pink fairy-duster"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Calliandra eriophylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12296,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Verbascum virgatum, or twiggy mullein, is drought-tolerant and prefers well-draining soil. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During its growing season in spring and summer, moderate watering is beneficial, but it’s crucial not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. In fall and winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy. A good rule of thumb is to water deeply but infrequently, simulating natural rainfall patterns, and always ensure excess water can drain away easily."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Verbascum virgatum thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. This plant is well adapted to sunny positions and is known for tolerating hot, dry conditions. Placing it in a sunny spot not only ensures optimal growth but also enhances its blooming potential. While it can survive in partial shade, too little sunlight can lead to leggy, weak growth and reduced flowering. Ensure it receives ample sunlight, especially in the early morning or late afternoon, to mimic its native habitat conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Verbascum virgatum involves removing spent flower spikes and any dead or damaged leaves. After the flowering period, typically in late summer, cut back the flowering stalks near the base to promote new growth and potentially encourage a second bloom. Additionally, remove any basal leaves that show signs of damage or disease to improve air circulation and plant health. In autumn, a light pruning to tidy up the plant and remove dead foliage helps prepare it for dormancy. Regular pruning helps maintain its shape and vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Wand Mullein","description":"Verbascum virgatum, commonly known as twiggy mullein and wand mullein, is a plant species in the family Scrophulariaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Wand Mullein"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Verbascum virgatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, from spring through early autumn, water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. Ensure the top inch of soil dries out between waterings to prevent root rot. In winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant enters dormancy and requires less moisture. It's important to adjust your watering based on local climate conditions, as Mediterranean honeysuckle's needs can vary with humidity and temperature changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lonicera implexa thrives in full sun to partial shade. While it can tolerate some shade, providing ample direct sunlight for at least 6 hours a day will result in the best growth and flowering. In areas with extremely hot summers, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch. When planting, choose a location that is sheltered from strong winds, which can damage the vine. Sunlight is crucial for this plant's health and vigor, influencing its flowering potential and overall growth behavior."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lonicera implexa is essential to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. The best time to prune this deciduous vine is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove all dead, damaged, or diseased wood, and cut back any overly vigorous shoots that disrupt the plant's shape. For aesthetic purposes and to encourage bushier growth, lightly trim the plant after flowering. Regular pruning helps to control its size and encourages more abundant blooming. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mediterranean Honeysuckle","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean region"],"other_name":["Mediterranean Honeysuckle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Lonicera implexa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12595,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Barbarea verna, commonly known as winter cress, requires moderate watering. Ensure the soil remains consistently moist, but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to root rot. During the growing season, regular watering is crucial to maintain the moist environment that the plant prefers. However, be cautious not to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. In hotter climates, you may need to water more frequently to compensate for evaporation. Monitoring the soil moisture and adjusting your watering schedule accordingly ensures healthy growth and abundant leafy greens."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Barbarea verna thrives best in full sunlight to partial shade. Ideally, provide at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day to support its growth. When planted in partial shade, especially during hot afternoons in warmer climates, the plant remains productive and less stressed. However, insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth where the plant stretches out to find light, reducing its overall vitality and leaf production. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent wilting and keep the plant lush and green, providing optimal growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Barbarea verna involves regularly harvesting the leaves because frequent pruning encourages bushier growth and prevents the plant from bolting, which is when it prematurely goes to seed. To prune effectively, use a pair of sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut the outer leaves, leaving the inner, younger leaves to continue the growth. This method not only provides fresh greens for culinary uses but also promotes a longer growing season. Remove any yellowing or damaged leaves to improve air circulation and reduce disease risks, ensuring the plant remains productive."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"land cress","description":"Land cress (Barbarea verna), also known as American cress, bank cress, black wood cress, Belle Isle cress, Bermuda cress, early yellowrocket, early wintercress, scurvy cress, creasy greens, and upland cress, is a biennial herb in the family Brassicaceae. It is native to southern Europe and western Asia, and naturalized elsewhere It has been cultivated as a leaf vegetable in England since the 17th century. As it requires less water than watercress, it is easier to cultivate.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["land cress"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Cabbage worms","Flea beetles"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Barbarea verna"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This plant is drought-tolerant and does not like its roots to stay wet. Watering should be done sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season, as this can reduce the number of flowers and subsequently, the number of capers produced."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Caper Bush","description":"Capparis spinosa, the caper bush, also called Flinders rose, is a perennial plant that bears rounded, fleshy leaves and large white to pinkish-white flowers.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean","Middle East","Central Asia"],"other_name":["Caper Bush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Capparis spinosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13592,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani, commonly known as soft-stem bulrush, is a wetland plant that thrives in saturated conditions. It prefers consistently moist to wet soil and can even tolerate standing water, making it ideal for water gardens and pond edges. Ensure that the roots remain submerged in water or consistently moist. They can handle water depths ranging from a few inches to several feet, but it should not be allowed to dry out. Regular watering to maintain moist conditions is key, especially if grown in containers or during dry periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It requires at least four to six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. However, it can tolerate some shade, particularly in hotter climates where a bit of relief from intense afternoon sun might benefit the plant. In full sun, it will display more vigorous growth and better blooms. When planted in water gardens or near pond edges, ensure it receives adequate sunlight to maintain its health and promote flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani involves removing dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth and maintain a tidy appearance. Cut back the stems close to the base as needed, particularly in late fall or early spring, to remove last season’s dead growth. During the growing season, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry. In the winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant goes dormant. If planting in a garden, choose a spot with ample morning sunlight or consistent all-day sun exposure to ensure vigorous growth and plentiful flowering. Avoid deep shade as it can significantly impact its blooming performance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Silphium compositum is not an intensive task. It's essential to cut back the spent flower stalks after blooming to encourage the plant's tidy appearance and to possibly promote a second bloom. In late fall or early spring, prune the dead foliage to make way for new growth in the upcoming season. Be careful not to cut too much green growth, as the plant doesn't need heavy pruning. Insect-prone foliage or diseased parts should be removed immediately to maintain the plant's health and vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Kidney-leaf Rosinweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Kidney-leaf Rosinweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Silphium compositum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In its natural habitat, it survives with minimal water from rainfall or snow melt, thus mimicking this natural watering pattern at home will help it thrive."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Silene acaulis prefers full sun to partial shade environments. It naturally grows in high-altitude, open areas where it receives ample sunlight, helping it to develop its dense mat formation which is essential for its growth. If grown indoors or in low-light conditions, ensure it receives bright, indirect light to mimic its natural alpine habitat as closely as possible."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Silene acaulis is minimal as it's a low-growing, compact cushion plant. Remove any dead or damaged foliage early in the growing season to maintain its health and appearance. After flowering, you can deadhead spent blooms to encourage a tidier look and, potentially, more extended blooming. Be careful not to damage the dense mat of foliage, which is crucial for its growth and protection against harsh conditions. Pruning is more about maintenance and less about shaping, focusing on keeping the plant healthy and vigorous."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Moss Campion","description":"Silene acaulis, known as moss campion or cushion pink, is a small mountain-dwelling wildflower that is common all over the high arctic and tundra in the higher mountains of Eurasia and North America, (south to the Alps, Carpathians, southern Siberia, Pyrenees, British Isles, Iceland, Faroe Islands, Rocky Mountains). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13993,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Asplenium australasicum, commonly known as the bird's nest fern, prefers consistent moisture. Ensure the soil is kept evenly moist but not waterlogged. Water when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch, typically needing more frequent watering in warmer months and less during the cooler months. It's crucial to avoid watering directly into the center of the fern (the rosette) as this may cause rot. Instead, water the soil around the perimeter of the plant. An environment with higher humidity, such as a bathroom, can also help maintain moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asplenium australasicum prefers indirect or filtered light. Direct sunlight can cause the fronds to scorch and lose their vibrant green color, so it's best to place it in a location that receives dappled sunlight, such as near a north or east-facing window where it gets morning sun. If direct light is unavoidable, consider using sheer curtains to diffuse it. In lower light conditions, while the fern can survive, its growth may slow. Keep an eye on the plant's leaves for signs of too much sun, and adjust its location as needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asplenium australasicum is generally minimal, focusing mostly on removing any dead or damaged fronds to maintain plant health and appearance. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut off affected fronds at their base, taking care not to damage the rosette at the plant's center. Regular removal of any yellowing or brown leaves can also improve air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of disease. Avoid over-pruning, as this can stress the plant and inhibit growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bird's nest fern","description":"Asplenium australasicum is a species of epiphytic fern in the Aspleniaceae family found in eastern Australia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12799,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Callitriche palustris, also known as water starwort, thrives in freshwater environments and does not require traditional watering. Instead, it grows best fully or partially submerged in water, such as in ponds, aquariums, or slow-moving bodies of water. It benefits from clean, well-oxygenated water and can tolerate a range of water conditions, although it prefers mildly alkaline water. There is no need for additional watering apart from maintaining the water level in its habitat. Keeping the water clean and replacing it periodically helps prevent algae growth and ensures healthy plant development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Callitriche palustris prefers moderate to bright indirect sunlight but can tolerate a range of light conditions. In a natural pond setting, it does well under partial shade, receiving filtered sunlight. In aquariums or tank environments, low to moderate lighting is adequate, simulating the dappled light of its natural habitats. Excessive direct sunlight can lead to rapid algae growth, which may compete with the plant for nutrients. Adjusting the plant’s sunlight exposure to match its growing conditions helps maintain balanced growth and prevents algae overgrowth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Callitriche palustris is typically unnecessary unless controlling its spread or ensuring it doesn’t overtake other aquatic vegetation. If needed, trim the plant back by removing older or overgrown stems, which will encourage healthier and bushier growth. Pruning can be performed throughout the growing season. When trimming, use clean scissors or shears to prevent infection, and avoid disturbing the roots. Removing decaying plant matter from the water will help maintain water quality and clarity, which is crucial for both the plant's health and the surrounding aquatic ecosystem."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Narrow-fruited Water-starwort","description":"Callitriche palustris, the vernal water-starwort, narrow-fruited water-starwort, or spiny water starwort, is a species of aquatic plants. During the growing season, water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. This encourages deep root development. Planting the tree in a location with abundant sunlight ensures a robust and healthy canopy. While it can tolerate partial shade, inadequate sunlight may lead to a sparse canopy and reduced vigor. In climates with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help mitigate stress, but generally, a sunlit location will support the best growth. Ensure the site is open enough to allow for expansion as the tree matures, maximizing light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Fraxinus velutina is best done in late winter or early spring while the tree is still dormant. This helps minimize stress and potential disease transmission. Begin by removing any dead, diseased, or damaged branches. Focus on maintaining a strong central leader by removing any competing stems or branches. Also, eliminate any crossing or rubbing branches to ensure good air circulation. This tree naturally grows with a pleasing shape, so avoid excessive pruning that may disturb its natural form. Regular pruning will help maintain tree health and a desirable structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"velvet ash","description":"Fraxinus velutina, the velvet ash or Arizona ash or Modesto ash, is a species of Fraxinus native to southwestern North America, in the United States from southern California east to Texas, and in Mexico from northern Baja California east to Coahuila and Nuevo León.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States","Northern Mexico"],"other_name":["velvet ash"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Borer","Scale"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Fraxinus velutina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Cut back overly vigorous branches to balance the growth and maintain an open center. It adapts well to different sunlight conditions, but optimal flowering and growth occur when provided with ample sunlight. Adjust planting location to match these light needs for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Physostegia virginiana helps promote vigorous growth and maintain its shape. After the flower spikes have bloomed, deadhead them by cutting the stalks back to near the base of the plant to encourage new blooms. In late fall, once flowering has finished and foliage begins to wither, you may also cut back stems nearly to the ground to tidy up the plant for winter. In practice, this will help reduce the plant's invasive tendency as it prevents unwanted seed dispersal. Regular thinning of overly dense growth will also keep the plants healthy and under control."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"obedient plant","description":"Physostegia virginiana (obedient plant, obedience, or false dragonhead) is a species of flowering plant in the mint family, Lamiaceae. It is native to North America, where it is distributed from eastern Canada to northern Mexico. Physostegia are known commonly as obedient plants because a flower pushed to one side will often stay in that position. The name “false dragonhead” refers to the dragonheads of the related Dracocephalum, a genus to which the plant once belonged.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["obedient plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Physostegia virginiana"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during growing seasons like spring and summer. Decrease the frequency of watering in the fall and winter when the plant grows more slowly. Always check the top few inches of soil before watering again – if it feels dry, then it's time to water. Using well-draining soil and pots with drainage holes can prevent root rot due to overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tibouchina urvilleana thrives best in bright, filtered sunlight. It prefers a location where it can receive a lot of indirect light, with some direct sunlight being beneficial but not during the hottest parts of the day. Ideally, morning sunshine is perfect, while afternoon shade helps protect it from intense sunlight, which may cause leaf burn. In frost-free regions, it can handle full sun if adequately watered. If grown indoors, placing Tibouchina near a south or west-facing window can provide sufficient light for healthy growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is an essential task to maintain the shape and encourage the dense growth of Tibouchina urvilleana. While it can tolerate partial shade, ideally it should be placed in a location with maximum sun exposure to ensure it does not become spindly or produce fewer flowers. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window to maximize sunlight access."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cirsium scariosum is generally not required frequently since it naturally maintains a tidy appearance. However, to encourage healthy growth and prevent it from becoming overly leggy, occasional pruning can be beneficial. Trim away any dead or damaged leaves by cutting them at the base with clean shears, and remove any flowers as they fade to prolong the blooming period and prevent self-seeding if desired. This will also direct the plant’s energy toward new growth. Additionally, cutting back the plant in late fall will help prepare for winter and encourage robust growth in the spring."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Elk Thistle","description":"Cirsium scariosum is a species of thistle known by the common names meadow thistle, elk thistle and dwarf thistle. This plant spreads through rhizomes, so every few years, consider dividing and thinning dense clumps to encourage better air circulation and prevent overcrowding. When dividing, ensure each section has a portion of the root system and healthy growth for replanting."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Canada mayflower","description":"Maianthemum canadense (Canadian may-lily, Canada mayflower, false lily-of-the-valley, Canadian lily-of-the-valley, wild lily-of-the-valley, Two-leaved Solomonseal) is a dominant understory perennial flowering plant, native to the sub-boreal conifer forests in Canada and the northern United States, from Yukon and British Columbia east to Newfoundland and south to Nebraska and Pennsylvania, and also in the Appalachian Mountains to northern Georgia. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings, as overwatering can lead to root rot. During the growing season, water the plant once a week or when the top inch of soil feels dry. In the winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant enters a period of dormancy. Always ensure the pot has good drainage to prevent water from sitting at the bottom. Monitoring the plant's leaves for signs of wilting or yellowing can also help adjust watering needs appropriately."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Araujia sericifera thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers a position with plenty of bright, indirect light but can tolerate periods of full sun. Indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight per day. If grown outdoors, ensure it has some protection from the harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch the leaves. Adequate sunlight promotes healthy growth and flowering; however, protect the plant from excessively strong light to prevent leaf burn and stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Araujia sericifera is essential to maintain its size and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems to improve air circulation. Cut back leggy or overly long growth to maintain the desired shape and size, as this plant can become quite vigorous. Be aware of its milky latex sap, which can be irritating to the skin, so it is advisable to wear gloves while pruning. Regular pruning also helps prevent unwanted spreading in the garden."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Moth Vine","description":"Araujia sericifera is a perennial ornamental plant in the genus Araujia belonging to Apocynaceae family. This plant was described in 1817 by the Portuguese botanist Félix Avelar Brotero. The synonym Araujia hortorum is in more frequent use in New Zealand. Its common names include moth plant, white bladderflower, common moth vine, cruel vine and false choko.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["Moth Vine"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Araujia sericifera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's best to prune dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth. Cutting back after flowering can help maintain a neat appearance and promote bushier growth. Removing the spent flowers, or deadheading, can prevent self-seeding if this is not desired, though it usually does not affect the plant's overall health. However, if you are cultivating them, it is useful to remove older, decaying specimens to prevent contamination and to allow room for new growth. Handling care is advised, as this species is toxic. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14087,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Monarda fistulosa, commonly known as wild bergamot or bee balm, prefers soil that is evenly moist but can tolerate some drought once established. Water the plant deeply and less frequently to encourage a deep root system. It is essential to allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Over-watering should be avoided, especially in areas with clay-heavy soils. In times of high heat or prolonged dry periods, be more vigilant about providing consistent moisture. The plant appreciates good drainage, so consider amending heavy soils with organic matter."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Monarda fistulosa thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of sunlight daily for optimal flowering. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. However, too much shade can lead to reduced blooming and a tendency for the plant to become leggy. Morning sun with afternoon shade is a preferred setup in warmer regions. Ensure the planting location has ample airflow, as this plant is susceptible to powdery mildew, which can be exacerbated by high humidity and poor circulation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is important to encourage healthy growth in Monarda fistulosa. In early spring, cut back any dead or damaged stems from the previous year. After the first bloom, you can deadhead the spent flowers to promote additional flowering and maintain a neat appearance. Around mid-summer, if the plant becomes too tall or leggy, trim back up to one-third of the stems to encourage bushier growth. In the fall, once the plant has died back, cut it to the ground to prepare it for the next growing season. This also helps prevent powdery mildew by removing affected leaves."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"wild bergamot","description":"Monarda fistulosa, the wild bergamot or bee balm, is a wildflower in the mint family (Lamiaceae) widespread and abundant as a native plant in much of North America. This plant, with showy summer-blooming pink to lavender flowers, is often used as a honey plant, medicinal plant, and garden ornamental. The species is quite variable, and several subspecies or varieties have been recognized within it.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["wild bergamot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Monarda fistulosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's also a good opportunity to remove any debris around the base of the plant to prevent fungal issues. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12499,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prosartes lanuginosa, commonly known as Yellow Mandarin or Hairy Fairy Bells, prefers consistently moist conditions. Make sure the soil is well-draining, yet able to retain some moisture. During the growing season, water the plant regularly to keep the soil damp but not waterlogged. Reduce watering in winter as the plant enters dormancy, ensuring the soil is only slightly damp to prevent root rot. It's important to establish a watering routine that creates an environment similar to its natural shaded woodland habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prosartes lanuginosa thrives best in partial to full shade, making it an ideal plant for woodland or shaded garden areas. It naturally grows under the canopy of trees, where it receives dappled sunlight or indirect light for the majority of the day. Avoid placing this plant in direct sunlight, especially the harsh afternoon sun, as it can scorch the leaves and inhibit growth. Aim to mimic its natural environment for optimal health and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Prosartes lanuginosa is minimal and typically involves removing any dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant health. Since this plant grows in a more natural, woodland setting, extensive pruning is unnecessary. It's best to monitor the plant and cut back any old or diseased stems after the flowering period is over. Cleaning up fallen leaves around the base can also prevent fungal issues while maintaining a tidy appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"yellow fairybells","description":"Prosartes lanuginosa is a North American plant species in the lily family with the common names yellow mandarin or yellow fairybells.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Canada"],"other_name":["yellow fairybells"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Prosartes lanuginosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12598,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trifolium wormskioldii, commonly known as cow clover or coastal clover, prefers moist conditions and should be watered regularly to maintain consistently damp soil, especially during dry periods. It's important to avoid waterlogging, which can damage the roots. In its natural habitat, this clover is found in wetlands and meadows, indicating its preference for adequate moisture. However, ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent standing water. During the growing season, monitor the soil moisture level every few days and adjust watering accordingly to prevent drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trifolium wormskioldii thrives in full sun to partial shade, making it adaptable to various light conditions. It prefers at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to flourish, although it can tolerate some afternoon shade, especially in hotter climates. An open, sunny position typically encourages robust growth and more abundant flowering. When planting, consider the seasonal sun patterns to ensure the location provides adequate light. In regions with intense heat, a spot with some afternoon shade can help prevent wilting and leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Trifolium wormskioldii is generally minimal and involves removing any dead or diseased stems and flowers to encourage healthy growth. This clover benefits from a seasonal trim to keep its appearance neat and to prevent it from becoming too unruly. Cutting back spent blooms can promote additional flowering. In the late fall or early spring, you may cut back the foliage to promote new growth for the upcoming season. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"springbank clover","description":"Trifolium wormskioldii is a species of clover. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13401,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Parnassia fimbriata, commonly known as the fringed grass of Parnassus, prefers consistently moist environments, mimicking its natural habitat near wetlands and stream banks. To care for this plant, ensure the soil remains damp but not waterlogged. Regular watering is essential, particularly in drier periods or when indoor humidity is low. Use water that is not too cold, and avoid letting the plant sit in standing water to prevent root rot. During the growing season, maintain a steady watering schedule, adjusting as needed based on the climate and soil drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parnassia fimbriata thrives in conditions that offer dappled sunlight or partial shade, as it typically grows in areas that naturally provide some cover from direct sunlight. However, it can tolerate full sun if the soil remains consistently moist. Ideally, a location that provides morning sun or filtered light through the day would promote optimal growth. In hotter climates, protecting the plant from intense afternoon sun with partial shade can help prevent stress and scorching. Adjust its placement according to seasonal changes to ensure it receives appropriate light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Parnassia fimbriata is minimal, as it is a low-maintenance plant. It generally requires only the removal of dead or damaged leaves to enhance its appearance and overall health. This can be done throughout the growing season. For better blooming, you can also remove spent flowers, which may encourage the plant to produce more blooms. Pruning is best done with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to minimize damage and the potential for disease. Regularly checking the plant for any signs of rot or pests will also help maintain its health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fringed Grass of Parnassus","description":"Parnassia fimbriata is a species of flowering plant in the family Celastraceae known by the common name fringed grass of Parnassus. It is native to western North America from Alaska and northwestern Canada to the southern Rocky Mountains, where it is a plant of alpine and subalpine environments.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Fringed Grass of Parnassus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Parnassia fimbriata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rich","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12299,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia apiana, commonly known as white sage, prefers a dry environment and requires infrequent watering. It is best to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can be a common issue, so ensure the plant has excellent drainage. Typically, watering every 10 to 14 days is sufficient, and during the winter months, watering should be reduced further. Always check the top few inches of soil; if they're dry, it is time to water. White sage is drought-tolerant and can survive with minimal water once established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia apiana thrives in full sun environments and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to flourish. This plant is native to arid regions and is accustomed to high light conditions, which help it produce the essential oils that are characteristic of white sage. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight. Insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and decreased vitality, so ensuring it gets enough sun is crucial for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia apiana should be done to encourage bushier growth and to remove any dead or damaged branches. The best time for major pruning is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. You can lightly prune after the plant finishes blooming in the summer to maintain shape. When pruning, make clean cuts above a leaf node to encourage regrowth. Removing spent flowers can also help prolong the blooming period. Avoid pruning too late in the fall as this can expose the plant to cold damage."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"white sage","description":"Salvia apiana (white sage, bee sage, or sacred sage) is an evergreen perennial shrub that is native to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico, found mainly in the coastal sage scrub habitat of Southern California and Baja California, on the western edges of the Mojave and Sonoran deserts.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["white sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Salvia apiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13696,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thymophylla tenuiloba, commonly known as Dahlberg Daisy or Golden Fleece, prefers moderate watering practices. It thrives in well-draining soil, so it's crucial to allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot; hence, water the plant deeply but infrequently, especially during its growing seasons in spring and summer. During cooler months, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows. Always check the soil moisture before watering by inserting your finger about an inch into the soil. If it feels dry, then it's time to water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thymophylla tenuiloba thrives best in full sun. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to maintain its vibrant blooms and healthy foliage. This plant highly tolerates and prefers sunny conditions, making it ideal for rock gardens, borders, and sunny windowsills indoors. Insufficient sunlight can lead to weak, leggy growth and reduced flowering. If growing indoors or in less sunny areas, ensure the plant receives adequate light by positioning it near a south- or west-facing window or supplementing with grow lights if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Thymophylla tenuiloba involves trimming back the plant to encourage fresh growth and maintain its shape. Regular deadheading, which is removing spent flowers, will promote continuous blooming throughout the growing season. This should be done in late spring or early summer. Additionally, prune any leggy stems to keep the plant compact and bushy. In late fall, cut back the plant to prevent overwintering pests and diseases. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears for best results."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"bristleleaf pricklyleaf","description":"Thymophylla tenuiloba, also known as the bristleleaf pricklyleaf, Dahlberg daisy, small bristleleaf pricklyleaf, golden fleece, or shooting star, is a bushy, multi-branched flowering annual from the family Asteraceae. Native to south central Texas and northern Mexico, it produces a large number of small, yellow flowers and demonstrates a trailing habit. It is tolerant of heat and dry conditions and is sometimes sold as a summertime annual plant in areas beyond its native range.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Texas","Mexico"],"other_name":["bristleleaf pricklyleaf"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Thymophylla tenuiloba"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravely"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12802,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calochortus weedii, commonly known as Weed's Mariposa Lily, is adapted to dry climates and requires minimal watering. It is crucial not to over-water this plant; allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to mimic its natural habitat. During its active growing season in the spring and early summer, water occasionally to provide moisture. However, during its dormant period, especially in the fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, only watering sparingly if at all, to prevent bulb rot. Good drainage is essential to its care."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calochortus weedii thrives in full sunlight to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive several hours of direct sunlight each day, mimicking the bright, open environments it naturally occurs in. In areas with extremely hot summers, partial afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent foliage from scorching. Ensure the plant gets plenty of morning sunlight to promote healthy growth and vibrant flowering. If grown indoors or in less optimal light conditions, consider supplementing with grow lights to provide adequate exposure consistent with its native environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Calochortus weedii is minimal and mainly involves cleaning up old foliage. After the plant has finished flowering and the seed heads have matured, you can trim back the flower stalks to the base. This helps the plant focus its energy on bulb and root health. Avoid cutting back the foliage while it is still green, as the bulbs store energy for next season’s growth during this period. Removing yellowed or dead leaves in late summer or fall is enough to keep the plant tidy without hindering its natural regrowth process."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Weed's Mariposa Lily","description":"Calochortus weedii is a North American species of flowering plants in the lily family known by the common name Weed's mariposa lily.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","USA"],"other_name":["Weed's Mariposa Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Calochortus weedii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
